Dear Ms. Ketchum:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints, elimination of restraints.
Description
1

(5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 1/09/24, youth was improperly restrained by a staff. The staff
carried youth out of the classroom and through the school,
towards the parking lot, and put the youth in the group home van.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1/ Complaint Source was interviewed face to face at the
facility on January 10, 2024. Staff 1 reported Supervisor asked her
to go up to Youth A’s school on January 9, 2023, because she was
struggling. She reported Youth A was upset during school because
she could not access YouTube due to looking up not approved
videos. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 was already at the school and was
trying to verbally redirect Youth A. She reported she brought Youth A
her blanket and bear which are her coping skills and she refused
both. Staff 1 stated Youth A became aggressive towards her and
began hitting, kicking, and attempting to bite her. She reported Youth
A’s teacher tried to talk to her and that did not work. Youth A kicked
Staff 1 in the stomach at one point. Staff 1 reported she attempted to
transport Youth A out of the area, but Youth A would drop her weight,
so she disengaged. Staff 1 reported she saw Staff 2 bear hugged
Youth A, picked her up, and carried her to the car. Youth A was still
upset when in the car but was able to calm down after a few minutes.
Staff 1 reported the way Staff 2 brought Youth A to the car was
inappropriate and not an approved hold they are trained. She
reported she heard Youth A stating she was upset because she does
not have a family and Staff 2 responded to Youth A that he does
have a family and he needs to go pick up his daughter. Staff 1
reported Staff 2 appeared to be overwhelmed with the situation.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on January
10, 2024. Youth A reported things have been going well at the
facility. Consultant asked Youth A how school was going, and she
reported that she had a hard day yesterday but did not want to talk
about it. She reported a staff goes with her to school for extra
support. Youth A reported she has been restrained before and was
able to explain what a restraint looks like. When asked if she was
ever in a restraint that was not done correctly, Youth A responded it
happened yesterday, but she already talked to Chief Administrator
about it. Youth A reported she was done talking with this consultant.
2

Staff 2 was attempted to be interviewed via phone on January
12, 2024, and January 18, 2024. This consultant attempted to
contact Staff 2 via phone on January 12, 2024, and January 18,
2024. A voicemail was left requesting a phone call back. Staff 2 is no
longer employed with the facility as of January 9, 2024. Staff 2 has
not returned contact to date.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
January 10, 2024. Supervisor reported she received a text message
from Staff 2 yesterday stating Youth A was struggling. She reported
she sent Staff 1 up to the school to be a support and bring Youth A
some comfort items. Supervisor reported when Staff 1 got back from
the school she explained the concern of Staff 2 picking up Youth A
and putting her in the car. Due to those concerns, Supervisor
encouraged Staff 1 to call this in as it was not an appropriate restraint
technique. Supervisor reported she contacted Chief Administrator on
the next steps of safety planning with Staff 2.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility
on January 10, 2024. Chief Administrator reported she talked with
Youth A briefly, but she did not go into details about what happened.
She reported Youth A continued to state she had a bad day, and she
was mean to staff. Chief Administrator reported earlier today she
talked with Staff 2 on the phone about the situation. She stated he
admitted he picked Youth A off the ground in a bear hug and brought
her to the car. Chief Administrator stated Staff 2 was aware that was
wrong but stated the school told him to do it. She reported she
confirmed with the school that no one told Staff 2 to carry Youth A
out of the building. Chief Administrator reported this school is an
alternative school and is trained in restraint management as well, so
they know that is not proper. Chief Administrator reported Staff 2 was
going to be terminated for his actions, but he ended up quitting
instead.
Documents Reviewed:
- MiSACWIS Incident Report number 171530214 dated
01/09/2024- This report was completed by Supervisor and
Staff1. This incident report is consistent with Staff 1’s
interview.
- Staff 2’s Human Resource File- Staff 2 was hired at the
facility in March 2023. Staff 2 did not have any disciplinary
actions due to inappropriate behavior with the youth or
completing a restraint inappropriately. Staff 2 completed CPI
restraint model training on 03/14/2023. Letter dated
01/15/2024 notes Staff 2 is no longer with the facility as of
01/09/2024 due to the incident involved within these
3

allegations. Staff 2 is noted to have resigned when being
asked about the situation from Chief Administrator.
- Email from Foster Care Worker dated 01/11/2024- Foster
Care Worker is Youth A’s Foster Care Worker. She reported
she visited with Youth A on 01/11/2024 and Youth A did not
want to talk to her about the incident. Foster Care Worker
reported she, Youth A’s Adoption Worker or a service
specialist see Youth A weekly.
- Facility Policy Physical Restraint Intervention dated
revision date 5/31/22- The facility utilizes the Crisis
Prevention Institute’s (CPI), Non-Violent Physical Crisis
Intervention philosophies when suing physical restraint
interventions with a client. The policy states, “Physical
restraint interventions must be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and considers the client’s chronological and
developmental age, size, medical and psychological
contraindications and gender in accordance with trained CPI
techniques.” The policy stated, “All physical restraint
interventions are performed by two staff members. No
individual staff member will perform a restraint by
themselves.”
- CPI Training Materials- The training materials does not allow
a hold of a bear hug or lifting the youth off the ground.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as Staff 1 was seen carrying
Youth A out of the school which is not an approved restraint
technique.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
